abstract.text: A container for all the ClassKit data in your app.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use the ClassKit data store to build and access contexts (
instances) that you use to advertise your app’s assignable content. Contexts in turn provide access to activities (
instances) that you use to record progress through assignments. You don’t instantiate a data store yourself. Instead, use the single
data store instance throughout your app.
The data store provides access to the app’s one and only main context through the
property. This property acts as the root context in your context hierarchy that you can use as a starting point when searching for descendant contexts.
To build contexts, you adopt the
protocol in one of your classes, typically one that exists for the lifetime of your app, and assign an instance of that class as the shared data store’s
property. Then, when the data store needs a context that it’s never seen before, it asks your delegate to build it.
After you make changes to any context, activity, or activity item, call the data store’s
method to commit the changes, and propagate them through the network.

abstract.text: Enable teachers to assign activities from your app’s content and to view student progress.
A representation of user interaction with a context.
Activity information that is true or false, pass or fail, yes or no.
An area of your app that represents an assignable task, like a quiz or a chapter.
A container for all the ClassKit data in your app.
The currently active context.
Marks all of the assigned and active activities for the given context path as complete.
Fetches all the contexts matching a predicate.
Fetches all the contexts along a given identifier path.
The data store delegate instance.
Fetches an activity for a given document so you can record progress on the associated task.
The app’s top-level context.
Marks a context for removal.
The currently running activity within the currently active context.
Saves any changes you’ve made in the data store.
The shared data store object.
An interface the data store uses to request new contexts.
The set of possible key paths you use to search for contexts.
Activity information that signifies a quantity.
Activity information that signifies a score out of a possible maximum.
Create and initialize missing contexts.
Prepare your app and your development environment to adopt ClassKit.
Walk through the process of setting up assignments and recording student progress.

doc://com.apple.classkit/documentation/C.title: Incorporating ClassKit into an Educational App

abstract.text: The ClassKit development or production environment for an education app that works with the Schoolwork app.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
